sen.j: 宝生流（ほうしょう-りゅう）は能楽の流派の一。
sen.e: The Hosho school is one of the Nohgaku (the art of Noh) schools.
The Hosho school is one of the Nohgaku (the art of Noh) schools.
The Hosho school is one of the Nohgaku (the art of Noh) schools.

sen.j: 現在、シテ方とワキ方（下掛宝生流）とがあり、それぞれ別の流儀である。
sen.e: There exist the shite-kata (actors who play leading characters) Hosho school and the waki-kata (supporting actors) Hosho school which is specially called Shimogakari Hosho school, and these are totally different schools.

There exist the shite-kata (actors who play leading characters) Hosho school and the waki-kata (supporting actors) Hosho school which is specially called Shimogakari Hosho school, and these are totally different schools.

There exist the shite-kata (actors who play leading characters) Hosho school and the waki-kata (supporting actors) Hosho school which is specially called Shimogakari Hosho school, and these are totally different schools.

sen.j: 単に「宝生流」というときはシテ方の宝生流をいうことが多い。
sen.e: When people simply mention the 'Hosho school,' it generally refers to the shite-kata Hosho school.
When people simply mention the 'Hosho school,' it generally refers to the shite-kata Hosho school.
When people simply mention the 'Hosho school,' it generally refers to the shite-kata Hosho school.

sen.j: また、かつて大鼓方にも「宝生流」「宝生錬三郎派」と呼ばれる流儀があったが、1986年に観世流の名に復した。
sen.e: In addition, there used to be the 'Hosho school' and the 'Hosho Renzaburo school' in the taiko-kata (drum specialists), but they were all restored to the Kanze school in 1986.
In addition, there used to be the 'Hosho school' and the 'Hosho Renzaburo school' in the Otsuzumi kata (large hand drum players), but they were all restored to the Kanze school in 1986.
sen.cmt: taiko-kata (drum specialists) → Otsuzumi kata (large hand drum player)
sen.e: In addition, there used to be the 'Hosho school' and the 'Hosho Renzaburo school' in the Otsuzumi kata (large hand drum players), but they were all restored to the Kanze school in 1986.

sen.j: 観世流に次ぐ第二の規模を誇る。
sen.e: They are the second biggest school after the Kanze school.
They are the second biggest school after the Kanze school.
They are the second biggest school after the Kanze school.

sen.j: 重厚な芸風で謡を重視し、その独特の謡の魅力から「謡宝生（うたいほうしょう）」とも呼ばれる。
sen.e: They emphasize Noh chants in their dignified performance style, and they are also called 'Utai Hosho' (literally, 'chanting Hosho') because of their unique chanting characteristics.

They emphasize Utai (the chanting of a Noh text) in their dignified performance style, and they are also called 'Utai Hosho' (literally, 'chanting Hosho') because of their unique chanting characteristics.
sen.cmt: Noh chants → Utai (the chanting of a Noh text)
sen.e: They emphasize Utai (the chanting of a Noh text) in their dignified performance style, and they are also called 'Utai Hosho' (literally, 'chanting Hosho') because of their unique chanting characteristics.

sen.j: 現宗家は2008年4月に宗家を継承した宝生和英（ほうしょうかずふさ）で二十世。
sen.e: The current headman is Kazufusa HOSHO, who succeeded to the head family in April 2008, and he is the 20th generation.
The current headman is Kazufusa HOSHO, who succeeded to the head family in April 2008, and he is the 20th generation.
The current headman is Kazufusa HOSHO, who succeeded to the head family in April 2008, and he is the 20th generation.

sen.j: 芸祖は観阿弥の長兄・宝生太夫。
sen.e: The founder of this school was Tayu HOSHO, who was the eldest brother of Kanami (a pioneering Noh playwright and performer who lived during the 14th century).
The founder of this school was Tayu HOSHO, who was the eldest brother of Kanami (a pioneering Noh playwright and performer who lived during the 14th century).
The founder of this school was Tayu HOSHO, who was the eldest brother of Kanami (a pioneering Noh playwright and performer who lived during the 14th century).

sen.j: 大和猿楽の外山座（とびざ）の流れを汲む。
sen.e: This school was descended from the Tobi-za, which was one of the performer groups of the Yamato Sarugaku (medieval Noh farce which was developed mainly in Yamato Province).
This school was descended from the Tobi-za, which was one of the performer groups of the Yamato Sarugaku (medieval Noh farce which was developed mainly in Yamato Province).
This school was descended from the Tobi-za, which was one of the performer groups of the Yamato Sarugaku (medieval Noh farce which was developed mainly in Yamato Province).

sen.j: 外山座はその看板役者・宝生太夫の名を取って宝生座と呼ばれるようになった。
sen.e: The Tobi-za then began to be called Hosho-za, named after Tayu HOSHO, who was the star performer of the group.
The Tobi-za then began to be called Hosho-za, named after Tayu HOSHO, who was the star performer of the group.
The Tobi-za then began to be called Hosho-za, named after Tayu HOSHO, who was the star performer of the group.

sen.j: 宝生座は多武峰や春日大社（若宮祭）、興福寺（薪猿楽）に参勤し、代々の宝生太夫は室町幕府に仕えた。
sen.e: The Hosho-za worked for shrines and temples on Mt. Tonomine, the Kasuga Taisha Shrine (at Wakamiyamatsuri Festival), and Kofuku-ji Temple (at Takigi-Sarugaku, an outdoor sarugaku play performed during the night), and every generation of Tayu HOSHO served the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).
sen.cmt: 原文では単に「多武峰」とありますが、ここでは多武峰にある神社仏閣のことを指しています。
sen.e: The Hosho-za worked for shrines and temples on Mt. Tonomine, the Kasuga Taisha Shrine (at Wakamiyamatsuri Festival), and Kofuku-ji Temple (at Takigi-Sarugaku, an outdoor sarugaku play performed during the night), and every generation of Tayu HOSHO served the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

The Hosho-za worked for shrines and temples on Mt. Tonomine, the Kasuga Taisha Shrine (at Wakamiyamatsuri Festival), and Kofuku-ji Temple (at Takigi-Sarugaku, an outdoor sarugaku play performed during the night), and every generation of Tayu HOSHO served the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

sen.j: 江戸時代には五代将軍徳川綱吉がとりわけ宝生流を贔屓し、他座の囃子方を宝生流に転属させるほどであった。
sen.e: In the Edo period, especially the fifth shogun Tsunayoshi TOKUGAWA liked the Hosho school so much that he told hayashi-kata (musical accompanists) of other schools to move to the Hosho school.
In the Edo period, especially the fifth shogun Tsunayoshi TOKUGAWA liked the Hosho school so much that he told hayashi-kata (musical accompanists) of other schools to move to the Hosho school.
In the Edo period, especially the fifth shogun Tsunayoshi TOKUGAWA liked the Hosho school so much that he told hayashi-kata (musical accompanists) of other schools to move to the Hosho school.

sen.j: またその頃、加賀藩主・前田綱紀の後援を受け、加賀の地では金春流に代わって宝生流が盛んとなった。
sen.e: Around that time, in Kaga Province, the Hosho school became dominant and took the place of the Konparu school backed up by Tsunanori MAEDA, who was the load of the Kaga Domain.
Around that time, with the support of Tsunanori MAEDA, who was the load of the Kaga Domain, the Hosho school became dominant and took the place of the Konparu school in Kaga Province.
sen.cmt: backed up by以下の意味が不正確と考えて再構成しました。
sen.e: Around that time, with the support of Tsunanori MAEDA, who was the load of the Kaga Domain, the Hosho school became dominant and took the place of the Konparu school in Kaga Province.

sen.j: 現在でも「加賀宝生」と呼ばれ、北陸では大きな勢力を誇る。
sen.e: That group is called 'Kaga Hosho' at present, and they are still one of the most influential schools in the Hokuriku region.
That group is called 'Kaga Hosho' at present, and they are still one of the most influential schools in the Hokuriku region.
That group is called 'Kaga Hosho' at present, and they are still one of the most influential schools in the Hokuriku region.

sen.j: その他「会津宝生」「南部宝生」「佐渡宝生」「久留米宝生」などの地域地盤が残る。
sen.e: The Hosho school still have some other regional branch schools such as 'Aizu Hosho,' 'Nanbu Hosho,' and 'Kurume Hosho.'
The Hosho school still have some other regional branch schools such as 'Aizu Hosho,' 'Nanbu Hosho,' 'Sado Hosho,' and 'Kurume Hosho.'
sen.cmt: 訳漏れ'Sado Hosho'を補足しました。
sen.e: The Hosho school still have some other regional branch schools such as 'Aizu Hosho,' 'Nanbu Hosho,' 'Sado Hosho,' and 'Kurume Hosho.'

sen.j: 十一代将軍徳川家斉も宝生流を愛好し、その隆盛を受け、1848年（弘化5年）には宝生太夫友干が大規模な勧進能を興行。
sen.e: The 11th shogun Ienari TOKUGAWA also loved the performance of the Hosho school, and Tayu-Tomoyuki HOSHO could have a large-scale performance of kanjin-Noh (Noh performances held to raise subscriptions for the construction of shrines or temples) in 1848 because of the prosperity of this school.

The 11th shogun Ienari TOKUGAWA also loved the performance of the Hosho school, and Tayu-Tomoyuki HOSHO could have a large-scale performance of kanjin-Noh (Noh performances held to raise subscriptions for the construction of shrines or temples) in 1848 because of the prosperity of this school.

The 11th shogun Ienari TOKUGAWA also loved the performance of the Hosho school, and Tayu-Tomoyuki HOSHO could have a large-scale performance of kanjin-Noh (Noh performances held to raise subscriptions for the construction of shrines or temples) in 1848 because of the prosperity of this school.

sen.j: この筋外橋門外での15日間の「弘化勧進能」は、江戸時代最大にして最後の勧進能となった。
sen.e: This 15 day-long performance called 'Koka Kanjin-Noh' held outside the Sujikaibashi-mon Gate was the biggest and the last kanjin-Noh performance of the Edo period.
sen.cmt: 原文には「筋外橋門」とありますが、こちらは誤字で正しくは「筋違橋門」と思われます。参考： http://db2.the-noh.com/edic/2009/08/kanjin_noh.htmlおよび http://db2.the-noh.com/jdic/2009/08/post_126.html
sen.e: This 15 day-long performance called 'Koka Kanjin-Noh' (Kanjin-Noh of Koka era) held outside the Sujikaibashi-mon Gate was the biggest and the last kanjin-Noh performance of the Edo period.
sen.cmt: (Kanjin-Noh of Koka era)を追加しました。
sen.e: This 15 day-long performance called 'Koka Kanjin-Noh' (Kanjin-Noh of Koka era) held outside the Sujikaibashi-mon Gate was the biggest and the last kanjin-Noh performance of the Edo period.

sen.j: 明治期の名人として宝生九郎知栄、松本金太郎 (能楽師)。
sen.e: Kuro-Tomoharu HOSHO and Kintaro MATSUMOTO were Noh masters of this school who lived during the Meiji period.
sen.cmt: 原文には「松本金太郎 (能楽師)」とありますが、リンク先の用語と混ざっていると思われます。ウェブを確認し、「松本金太郎」として訳出いたしました。
sen.e: Kuro-Tomoharu HOSHO and Kintaro MATSUMOTO were Noh masters of this school who lived during the Meiji period.
Kuro-Tomoharu HOSHO and Kintaro MATSUMOTO were Noh masters of this school who lived during the Meiji period.

sen.j: その薫陶を受けた松本長、野口兼資、近藤乾三、高橋進 (能楽師)などの名人を多く輩出している。
sen.e: Also, many great performers who were trained in the Hosho school's performance appeared; for example, Nagashi MATSUMOTO, Kanesuke NOGUCHI, Kenzo KONDO, and Susumu TAKAHASHI.
sen.cmt: 原文には「高橋進 (能楽師)」とありますが、リンク先の用語と混ざっていると思われます。ウェブを確認し、「高橋進」として訳出いたしました。
sen.e: Also, many great performers who were trained in the Hosho school's performance appeared; for example, Nagashi MATSUMOTO, Kanesuke NOGUCHI, Kenzo KONDO, and Susumu TAKAHASHI.
Also, many great performers who were trained in the Hosho school's performance appeared; for example, Nagashi MATSUMOTO, Kanesuke NOGUCHI, Kenzo KONDO, and Susumu TAKAHASHI.

sen.j: 当代の名人として三川泉、近藤乾之助がいる。
sen.e: Izumi MIKAWA and Kennosuke KONDO are great performers of this school of our day.
Izumi MIKAWA and Kennosuke KONDO are great performers of this school of our day.
Izumi MIKAWA and Kennosuke KONDO are great performers of this school of our day.

sen.j: ワキ方
sen.e: Waki-kata
Waki-kata
Waki-kata

sen.j: 下掛りである金春流に属したワキ方春藤流から分かれた。
sen.e: The Hosho school of waki-kata was descended from the Shundo school, which was a branch waki-kata school of the Konparu school, and the Konparu school was included in Shimogakari (a generic name given to the Konparu school, the Kongo school, and the Kita school).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The Hosho school of waki-kata was descended from the Shundo school, which was a branch waki-kata school of the Konparu school, and the Konparu school was included in Shimogakari (a generic name given to the Konparu school, the Kongo school, and the Kita school).

The Hosho school of waki-kata was descended from the Shundo school, which was a branch waki-kata school of the Konparu school, and the Konparu school was included in Shimogakari (a generic name given to the Konparu school, the Kongo school, and the Kita school).

sen.j: そのためシテ方宝生流と区別して「下掛宝生流」「下宝生」「脇宝生」などと呼ばれる。
sen.e: Therefore they are also called 'Shimogakari Hosho-ryu (school),' 'Shimo-hosho,' or 'Waki-hosho' in order to distinguish this school from the shite-kata Hosho school.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Therefore they are also called 'Shimogakari Hosho-ryu (school),' 'Shimo-hosho,' or 'Waki-hosho' in order to distinguish this school from the shite-kata Hosho school.
Therefore they are also called 'Shimogakari Hosho-ryu (school),' 'Shimo-hosho,' or 'Waki-hosho' in order to distinguish this school from the shite-kata Hosho school.

sen.j: 江戸初期、三代将軍徳川家光の命で、春藤流の金春権七祐玄が宝生座付きとなったのがはじまり。
sen.e: This school started when Gonshichi KONPARU, who later started to call himself Yugen, was assigned to the Hosho school from the Shundo school by the third shogun Iemitsu TOKUGAWA in the early Edo period.

This school started when Gonshichi KONPARU, who later started to call himself Yugen, was assigned to the Hosho-za from the Shundo school by the order of the third shogun Iemitsu TOKUGAWA in the early Edo period.
sen.cmt: Hosho school → Hosho-zaby the order of theに変更しました。
sen.e: This school started when Gonshichi KONPARU, who later started to call himself Yugen, was assigned to the Hosho-za from the Shundo school by the order of the third shogun Iemitsu TOKUGAWA in the early Edo period.

sen.j: 二世新之丞の時、宝生を名乗る。
sen.e: The second generation Shinnojo started to use the family name Hosho.
The second generation Shinnojo started to use the family name Hosho.
The second generation Shinnojo started to use the family name Hosho.

sen.j: 明治時代の名人として宝生新、松本謙三。
sen.e: Arata HOSHO (also called Shin HOSHO) and Kenzo MATSUMOTO were masters of the Hosho school of the Meiji period.
Arata HOSHO (also called Shin HOSHO) and Kenzo MATSUMOTO were masters of the Hosho school of the Meiji period.

sen.j: ついで森茂好、宝生弥一。
sen.e: Shigeyoshi MORI and Yaichi HOSHO appeared after them.
Shigeyoshi MORI and Yaichi HOSHO appeared after them.
Shigeyoshi MORI and Yaichi HOSHO appeared after them.

sen.j: 当代の名人として宝生閑、森常好が東京を中心に活躍。
sen.e: At present, masters such as Kan HOSHO and Tsuneyoshi MORI show great performances in and around Tokyo.
At present, masters such as Kan HOSHO and Tsuneyoshi MORI show great performances in and around Tokyo.

sen.j: 現宗家は宝生閑で十二世。
sen.e: The current headman is Kan HOSHO, and he is the 12th generation headman.

sen.e: Taiko-kata
